titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Developing Countries Program, Office Files of William D. Carmichael
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Developing Countries Program, Office Files of William D. Carmichael FA711

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-10-09 01:31:17 -0400.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Developing Countries Program, Office Files of William D. Carmichael

physdesc.extent: 48 boxes (45 letter document boxes, 2 half letter document containers, 1 legal document container)

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: William D. Carmichael was Vice President of the Ford Foundation, Developing Country Programs from 1981-1989. The administration of the Ford Foundation international programs was dramatically restructured in 1980-1981, and a new office for Developing Country Programs was created. William D. Carmichael was appointed Vice President of this new area in March 1981. Carmichael oversaw the work of Foundation field offices, and of New York-based staff responsible for grants to developing countries. Prior to his role as Vice President, he was Head of the Middle East and Africa Office (1977-1981), Head of the Office for Latin America and the Caribbean (1971-1977) and Representative in the Brazil Office (1968-1971). Dr. Carmichael retired from the Ford Foundation on September 30, 1989. Key accomplishments of Carmichael's tenure as Vice President include his role in advancing the development of a Women's Program, financing for worldwide activities in community resource management, the expansion of Foundation activities throughout southern Africa. Carmichael and his staff played a leading role within the U.S. philanthropic and scholarly communities in the formulation of policies towards the apartheid regime in South Africa. After leaving the Ford Foundation, he became executive director for Soviet Union and Eastern European Programs at the Institute of International Education until 1993.

Born on September 5, 1929, Dr. William D. Carmichael received a B.A. in Economics from Yale in 1950. In 1952 he received an M.P.A. in Public and International Affairs and an M.A. in Economics from Princeton University. He received a BLitt from Oxford University in Economics in 1955, and was awarded a PhD in Economics by Princeton in 1959. Before working at the Foundation, Dr. Carmichael served as Dean of Cornell University's Graduate School of Business and Public Administration from 1962 until 1968.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Office Files of William D. Carmichael document Ford Foundation overseas grants during the period 1968-1989, with an emphasis on the 1980s. The bulk of the records concern Carmichael's work as Vice President, Developing Country Programs, and consist of correspondence, memos and reports pertaining to the administration and grant activities of Ford Foundation field offices around the world. The collection also documents the relationship between overseas offices of the Ford Foundation and the headquarters in New York City. There are substantial records documenting Carmichael's travel and attendance at conferences, his participation in Board of Trustee meetings and his role in coordinating Board meetings convened overseas. Also included are budget planning records, program review documents, and subject files relating to numerous program initiatives and administrative matters of concern to Carmichael. The collection is particularly rich in material concerning the daily operations of field offices around the world, Ford Foundation-funded educational programs in South Africa, and the international component of the Foundation's Women's Program.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Office Files of William D. Carmichael are arranged in eight series:

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. The entirety of Series 6: Board of Trustees, 1978-1989 is restricted from access. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

When requesting to view audiovisual material, please refer to the Title and the AV Number (example: AV 1916). Researchers are asked to check the "Restrictions" note for each Title. If a Title does not currently have an access copy, please contact a RAC archivist for further instruction.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use". If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the users responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: William D. Carmichael's material arrived at the RAC in three accessions between 2011 and 2019. The material that arrived in 2011 and 2012 was processed as two separate collections at the RAC. When another box of Carmichael material arrived at the RAC in 2019, all of Carmichael's files were consolidated into one collection and brought up to standard processing by Katie Martin in February 2020.

The material in Series 1-6 came to the RAC in 2012 as Accession 2012:068 [Boxes 30272-30275, 30277-30280, 30282, 47940-47942]. The material was received by the Ford Foundation archive staff in 1990. This material was originally arranged and described by Jim Moske, Ford Foundation Archives, in 2006.

The material that comprises Series 7: Chronological Correspondence Files came to the RAC in 2011 as Accession 2011:075. The material was originally processed by Brian Bleich and Nancy Ng Tam, The Winthrop Group, in August 2011 as a standalone collection, A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Developing Countries Program, Correspondence Files of William D. Carmichael (FA522). This material became Series 7 of Ford Foundation records, Developing Countries Program, Office Files of William D. Carmichael in February 2020.

Series 8 is comprised of material from Accession 2019:101 [Box 40044] that was originally separated from the rest of Carmichael's papers. The box arrived at the RAC from the Ford Foundation in 2019. The materials were processed and added to this collection by Katie Martin in February 2020.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at https://rockarch.org/collections/access-and-request-materials/#citations

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: William D. Carmichael's material arrived at the RAC in three accessions between 2011 and 2019. The material that arrived in 2011 and 2012 was processed as two separate collections at the RAC. When another box of Carmichael material arrived at the RAC in 2019, all of Carmichael's files were consolidated into one collection and brought up to standard processing by Katie Martin in February 2020.
Most of the description created by previous processors has been retained and the order of files within series is unchanged.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, memoranda, reports, press clippings and other records that document program development, grantmaking and grantee activities. Also included are records concerning the establishment, administration and daily operations of overseas offices. Numerous memos and reports written by Program Officers include vivid accounts of the political scene, current events and social and economic conditions in their host countries. Many reports contain general histories of regions or countries, as well as overviews of Foundation activities in these areas. Also included are files concerning the opening of new offices in China and Zimbabwe, and on transferring the West Africa office from Lagos, Nigeria to Dakar, Senegal. The bulk of the series dates from the 1980s, though scattered memos and reports from the 1970s are also present.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The records are arranged alphabetically by the region, with further sub-division by program officer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, memoranda and supporting documents concerning grantmaking and investment in South Africa by the Ford Foundation and other organizations. Includes files of Assistant Program Officer David Bonbright, and records of a committee of foundation and university executives convened by the Carnegie Corporation to promote better educational opportunities for black South Africans.

did.unittitle: Consortium on Educational Opportunities for Black South Africans
Fund for Education in South Africa

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, memoranda, notes, agendas, reports, program submissions and briefing materials relating to William Carmichael's travel abroad on Foundation business, and his attendance at conferences and meetings worldwide. Events documented in these files include Ford Foundation staff meetings, field office site visits and conferences sponsored by other organizations. Of particular importance are extensive files on the 1985 United Nations Nairobi Conference marking the end of the Women's Decade, the 1983 meetings of the Ford Foundation International Affairs and Human Rights and Social Justice programs in Geneva, Switzerland, and a 1982 New York meeting of Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi with representatives of American philanthropies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Program budget submissions and related documentation from DCP and a few other Foundation divisions. Many files include substantive reports on the political, social, and economic climates of various countries in which the Foundation had offices. The Program Review files contained in Series V are closely related to these budget materials.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files are arranged alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains records concerning miscellaneous program initiatives, administrative matters, outside organizations and topics of general interest to Carmichael. Included are DCP program review files, memos and reports concerning the origins of the Women's Program and the Health, Nutrition and Population Program, and correspondence concerning the Bilateral Commission on United States-Mexican Relations (access to the latter is restricted from scholarly access).

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Select files are restricted from scholarly access as noted.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, memoranda, agendas, reports, briefing books and travel information, relating primarily to overseas meetings coordinated by William Carmichael and his staff. Included in some files are Carmichael's handwritten notes on meeting proceedings, and outlines for several of his presentations to the Board. Also a few files of correspondence with, and travel reports by, individual board members. Meeting minutes, dockets, reports and committee files previously and separately collected by the Archives are not included here. Access restricted.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: All contents of Series VI are restricted from scholarly access.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains Dr. Carmichael's chronological correspondence files dating from 1971 to 1989. The files from October 1981 to 1989 are arranged in yearly increments and then alphabetically by recipient's last name.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This series was originally a separate collection, Ford Foundation records, Developing Countries Program, Correspondence Files of William D. Carmichael (FA522) The original finding aid was created by Brian Bleich and Nancy Ng Tam, The Winthrop Group in August 2011. This collection was added as a correspondence series to Ford Foundation records, Developing Countries Program, Office Files of William D. Carmichael by Katie Martin in February 2020 to consolidate Carmichael's materials into one collection. The order of the material is unchanged.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Other information about the Africa and Middle East (AME) Programs can be found in Program Staff Files, 1965-1976, 1987-1994 (FA503). Additional information about the Developing Countries Program can be found in the Program Staff Files, 1960-1983. The files were maintained by Elisa Scatena and Richard W. Dye, both of whom reported to Dr. Carmichael as head of DCP. A portion of these files have been transferred to Rockefeller Archive Center as FA528 Ford Foundation records, Developing Countries Program, Program Staff Files, 1973-1978. Ford Foundation records, Developing Countries Program, Vice President, Office files of William D. Carmichael, 1968-1989, document his oversight of the administration and program activities of Foundation field offices around the world, and of New York-based program staff responsible for grants in developing countries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The files begin with Dr. Carmichael's appointment as head of the Office of Latin America and the Caribbean (OLAC) and continue through to his retirement in 1989. During this time, he also directed the Middle East and Africa (MEA) office and served as Vice President of the Developing Countries Program (DCP). The files include correspondence with and memoranda about grantees, including approvals for grant extensions and modifications. Memoranda in the files also discuss issues regarding Foundation policy such as budget review questions and internal affirmative action policy.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Series 8 is comprised of material from Accession 2019:101 [Box 40044] that arrived at the RAC in 2019. The files in this series came to the RAC described as "to be catalogued." A note on the original inventory stated that the material was "removed from Carmichael collection." These materials were processed and added to Ford Foundation records, Developing Countries Program, Office Files of William D. Carmichael by Katie Martin in February 2020.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The reports in this series were originally separated by the Ford Foundation from the rest of Carmichael's collection for further cataloging. The reports were added back after documentation indicated the material belonged with Carmichael's paper. Many of the reports in this series are from the Urban Mathematics Collaborative Project funded by the Ford Foundation.
